titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: James Wood (1839-1925) attended Westtown School and Haverford College. He served for many years as a manager of both Haverford College (1885-1918) and Bryn Mawr College (1887-1918), and was founder and President of the Board of Managers of the New York State Reformatory for Women (1900-1918). He was also President of the Hampshire Downs Breeder's Association, President of the American Bible Society, and a contributor to The Friends Review, The American Friend, and Country Gentlemen. He was the 1886 nominee of Republican Congressional Convention. He spent much of his life in Mount Kisco, New York.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of James Wood. Materials include: correspondence on Quaker theology, agriculture, and the Wood family's two-year European travels; photograph albums from the European journey; lectures on a wide range of topics, including Native Americans, Quaker theology and practice, the history of the American Friends, and government; newspaper clippings and pamphlets on Quaker topics; newspaper clippings on agricultural topics; documents related to Wood's farm, including flock records, photographs, bills and receipts, and award certificates; personal financial records; correspondence with family and friends; a holograph manuscript and a typed transcript of Wood's memoir, "The Education of James Wood," and a typescript of Wood's "The Past: Reminiscences of the Wood Family and Braewold." The collection also includes a small batch of family photographs of the Wood family (including Morris Wistar Wood and Curtis Wood from the 1950s and 1960s) and the Wistar family (from the 1860s-1880s).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

otherfindaid.p: An inventory is available in the repository.
